description.text: Made landing gear longer, and increase angle to 70deg to compensate for longer length.

I work at a camp where I help teach a 3D printing class, and one of the projects we do is have them build a Printrbot simple that they get to keep. One of the big problems we kept having though is that when you ran the wires through they'd either be so thick that they'd lift the printer and cause it to rock uncontrollably or that they'd have to go in at some strange angle that made the printer tilt. So in order to remedy that I designed these little feet that'll raise the printer half an inch off the ground.

They can all fit on the Printrbot simple print bed, although you have to make sure the back leg is at a 45 degree angle since it's slightly longer than 4 inches. I printed two front legs and had them on both sides of the printer. You could use one front leg, but it does tend to wobble from side to side if you do. They're also tight enough that they should stay on even when you lift the printer.
I made them with 5% infill, 1mm shells, and .2mm resolution out of PLA. No rafts, no supports, just make sure they're positioned properly.

description.text:
This is my first attempt at creating 3D printable text.
It is based on the inspirational slogan of the incredible Podcaster/Independent Film Maker Ryan Connolly who is constantly reminding film makers to always Write, Shoot, Edit Repeat... If you aren't familiar with him or his show Film Riot, you should be! Visit them on the internets at:
https://www.youtube.com/user/filmriot Update #1: 8/10/14 - Did my first test print. Model clearly needs some work :(
I need to figure out how to land the design flat on the base as it is not completely flat horizontally so needs supports to print level...Also, the letters E, A, and the bottom of the R needs more space to look right. I will try to figure this out and make corrections. Update #2 : 8/17/14 - So I changed the fonts to go with the theme of the design which is obviously movies.
Write - Jurassic Park
Shoot - Back to the Future
Edit - The Goonies
Repeat - Charlie and the Chocolate Factory
I also changed the cube at the bottom to be flush with the words so it should no longer need supports if printed on the backside...I am starting a test print now and will post results and pictures.
Update #3: 8/17/14 - Printing without rafts/supports did not go so well...looks like I failed to ensure the cube i used for the base and the words were totally flush...Had to abort the first test print. Have since re-started with rafts and supports and is looking much more usable. 1hr in to the print with 2:55 remaining. I will post results and pictures when done.
Update #4 9/1/14 - Printed with rafts/supports pretty successfully.
Goal is still to get it completely flush so it can just be printed on it's back without support, but to be completely honest I am still learning my way around 3D space in Photoshop. If I can figure it out I will post an updated .stl here and will name it WSER_No Supports. Until you see that you are warned... Overall I am pretty happy with it as the very first thing I have ever created on my own without downloading.

Designed in Photoshop CC.
Printed on DaVinci 1.0 with rafts/supports due to the words not being flush with the back of the base.
If I can figure it out I will post an updated .stl here and will name it WSER_No Supports. Until you see that you are warned...

title: FlexMesh 1.0 -- Flexible Chainmail Mesh
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Update: Now check out FlexMesh 2.0 which takes FlexMesh to the next level. FlexMesh suggests a few interesting ways to think outside the box when designing for today's 3D printers.
  • Plastic is fairly rigid, but with the proper geometry some objects printed with plastic can be flexible, durable and strong.
  • Flat shapes can be folded to form tall objects, and tall shapes can be flattened to great lengths.
  • The build area of your printer is 2D, but the build volume is 3D.
  • Your printer's build volume only confines the size of your print jobs, not the full size of your project.
    Suggest other ways we can overcome the limits of 3D printing today.
    • Updates...

  • Makerbot slicers are now supported for single-layer meshes.

  • TriSphere is another flexible mesh pattern worth exploring.

Makerbot and Simplify3D slicers has been successfully used to print these shapes. All prints have only been done using ABS on FlashForge printers with a layer height of 0.2mm, 2 shells and a 10% infill. The longest length mesh printed so far is about 8.5 feet. (This 147mm tall print consumed almost 2kg of filament and took a FlashForge Creator X 200 hours to complete.) Filaments used to produce flexible and durable joints include Octave and Zen Toolworks.    
Simple dimensional drawings have been uploaded that show the individual shapes of the mesh as well as the dimensions of various useful shape combinations. The mesh was intentionally designed for easy manipulation. All the flat shapes are 6.75mm tall. Both the large and small shapes (which are called 'main' and 'sub', respectively) repeat every 25mm in both the X and Y dimensions. Successive vertical layers of fabric are always 7mm above the layer below. The 'short sub' shape (which is 14mm tall) is used to connect Main objects of adjacent layers.   
Single layer meshes are printed without a raft or supports. However multi-layer jobs require that big supports be manually added below every Short Sub part using Simplify3D's super-handy manual-supports feature of Simplify3D. Support for multi-layer prints using Makerbot slicers is still being worked on.   
Joints should rotate immediately after printing, though unusually stiff joints should be allowed to cool in order to reduce the chance of a peg shearing. A small tool head wiggled and wedged in between the corners of a main should all that's necessary to separate vertical layers of mesh.   
Larger meshes are constructed by using pegs to join a Main to a Sub. Note that the last few millimeters of one end of a peg has a slightly larger diameter in order to keep the peg seated in the Main. Snips can be used to trim the length of a peg if it sticks out further than desired.    
Have fun and please take the time to submit remixes for the benefit of all.

This is a cut-way sectional of the enzyme hydrogenase. Hydrogenase is an important enzyme in biology and in biotechnology applications. Hydrogenase takes protons and electrons and forms hydrogen gas (or performs the reverse reaction), and thus it is capable of converting water into hydrogen gas, in the presence of a reducing agent.
I added four of the iron-sulfur clusters and the actual di-iron active site with all the ligands. This is a nice example of how nature has brought together very intricate clusters and arranged them to make a very nice catalyst. I finished my model and painted the various cofacters (sulfur yellow and iron green), along with some of the secondary structure. Really happy with how this one turned out. I painted the braces with a steel paint to indicate that they are not really part of the structure.

This was printed on a Makerbot II at medium quality with a raft. There is no need for supports, as I have added these in individually. The first print turned out very good. I added some braces in a few spots that didn't print well, but it should be good to go now. This one may take me a while to paint, but I thought I would provide it here in case someone else wanted to print it out. It took about an hour to remove the braces and another hour with an modeling knife to clean off the surfaces.

This is a simple model using the Printrbot logo to go with a tutorial on making printable models in Blender.
You can find the tutorial here:
http://youtu.be/YjVSI6zTQm0

This was built in Blender using the Bezier curve tool to trace the basic logo. The curve was converted to a mesh object, closed then extruded to give it depth.
The main pitfalls of using Blender are:
1) Scale. One Blender unit equals 1 mm in the real world.
2) Normals. Make sure all the faces that are supposed to be exterior are pointing out as they should.
The logo was traced from this image:
http://printrbot.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/07/printrbot_logo.png

title: Safe and secure Raspberry Pi B+ Case

description.text:
Made from the ground up, with the use of the model of the Raspberry Pi B+ model I published here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:402498 and of course an actual board I used for test fit the case (drawing go so far). Overall, I used .2 and .25 mm gaps so, this case is a TIGHT FIT. Meant to securely house a Raspberry Pi B+ v1.2 2014 board using 4x 20mm M3 socket head screws. It is a "natural" evolution of the case I made for the previous version of the Raspberry Pi B board found here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:209100 You can also find a similar case for the Raspberry Pi A+ board I made here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:566506 Raspberry Pi 3 B:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1427797 Enjoy. Update, added new honeycomb top upon request.

This is the setup I used
.35 mm j-head
.25 mm layer height
125% for first layer
80% rectilinear in-fill
Fan always on except for first layer
2 vertical perimiters
2 bottom layers
2 top layers
This case was designed for .25 mm layer height.
Print a bottom and a top part without support.
Use 4x M3 20mm hex head to fasten.

comments.text: Wow, my first reply...thanks for the interest! I believe your asking if the magnets ever just "split" from flying hard, turning, ect.. Yes! they did, at first I was using 1/4" by 1/4" cylinder magnets. With those magnets did split twice and the copter spun out of control.  Two month ago I upped the size to 3/8" x 1/4" and haven't had a problem since. I've crashed and they split as they should but, still hold during flight. I'm not sure if I ordered the N48 strength or N52s, probably buy the N52s to make sure. Thanks again!!   copterbuild.com

comments.author: dragonflyRC

comments.text:
I built this copter for the first timer to intermediate in mind so, it runs a 3cell 2200mah battery with turnigy 950kv and multistar 30amp ESCs. The battery mounts in side the canopy so you have the option of running a second battery in parallel underneath the body. It seems to be coming kind of a standard for the motor mounts to be a 4 bolt cross pattern between 32mm and 35mm for kinda medium motors. The mounts are slotted to accommodate. I've also ran larger turnigys (910kv), that can handle a 4cell. They had a larger 4 bolt cross mount and that's the other foot pattern you can download. The 30amp ESCs can handle them but, the larger battery was mounted underneath. The props, 12" for response and the sound when cutting hard.
Philsson, this is great! Thank you for asking..
comments.author: philsson

comments.text: No probs.. of course. Was curious ;) I am running a similar setup myself. Have 750kv motors, 3cell battery and 11" props. I am starting to think maybe 11" are too big. I've been running 10" before and the copter seemed quicker then but have also gone from multiwii to arducopter so I really cant tell. Lots of people seem to be running 4 or 5S and lower kv motors for longer flight time which is something that would be interesting to try. Also my first tri and never had anything else before either.

Filament guide to help feed the filament off the spool at a consistent rate.  Attach a PTFE tube (4mm outer diameter, 3mm inner diameter) to one side, and run it to the extruder (make sure it's long enough for the full range of the extruder).  Running the filament through the tube should keep the spool from being yanked around as the extruder moves.  The spool should turn at the rate the extruder feeds.  I spiral the filament tube around the extruder cable a couple of times and have it attached with a velcro strap.  
Update: The original part has more resistance than it should, especially when you get to the end of the spool and the diameter decreases.  The new v2 version is designed to attach further away (usually the top rear bar).

description.text: Drone or worker, you decide.

Here is a cat toy; a hollow sphere containing a few bells and decorated by piercing the walls with cat images.
My daughter's cat likes it although like most cats it happily chases almost any ball.  The cat image comes from MaakMijnldee's cookie cutter collection - thing:35495. Other images are included in the openSCAD code.
The sphere has a pentagonal opening; the lid is printed separately and attached with acetone or glue after the bells are placed inside.  The bells came from a craft store and are often called "jingle bells".  I used the half inch size

Both the body of the sphere and the lid need to be printed with external support.
Animals_dxf.zip has to be expanded and available to the openSCAD code when it is executed.  It holds the cat dxf file and other images.
The openSCAD code produces both parts at once as an stl file with two shells.  I used MeshLab"s "Select Connected Components in a Region" command to separate the two shells.  The lid has been scaled by a factor of 1.015 to better fit the opening.
The openSCAD code includes instructions for generating the toy as a single shell without the opening.

Calibration block in metric units. Contains 11 different 3D printer calibration tests. Model is solid so I recommend printing partial fill.
English units version: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:217369 Be sure to print 1:1 scale so the tests are accurate! (Assuming your printer is sufficiently calibrated) Tests:
horizontal and vertical hole diameters
3-axis feature minimum feature width test
scaling accuracy (via 10mm^3 cube cutout)
rounded feature minimum size
fillet minimum size
Vertical and horizontal max tower height to diameter ratio
Max build hangover angle test (30 - 80 degrees)
minimum layer thickness
Bug fixes:
Fixed text order on some of the labels.
added a horizontal pillar protrusion test. Yes, that makes it 12 now.
lengthened the minimum layer height test.

comments.text:
Errr, Uhhh. Mine doesn't look so hot...
The text is terrible on the top. Lines and circles look great.
comments.author: gddeen

comments.text:
Several of the tests on this calibration block require the use of calipers to measure the minimum feature thickness and to verify that 10mm on the model is actually 10mm on the part. I chose to go with non discrete test sizes for several features because the size of this calibration block would be even bigger than it already is. The text on the top may not look so great depending on a variety of factors including your print head nozzle diameter (assuming you're using FDA), along with nozzle temperature and other calibration parameters. It's hard to immediately diagnose without knowing your machine is calibrated decently well.
This is very generic, but you might look at some some calibration guides online. If you can find one specific to your printer and/ or software, that's even better.
http://reprap.org/wiki/Calibration

description.text:
This is a printable mold so you can cast Moai out of something else. Note that the neck is a little narrower than the head, so you'll have to cast out of a material that is at least a little flexible to demold. I used Oogoo..This was a bit of an experiment to see if casting something larger in Oogoo would actually work at all. It turns out it works beautifully, and I'm pretty sure I could go much larger...I would however recommend you try your hand at casting a few smaller things with Oogoo before you try something this large. You can find the recipient for Oogoo here:
http://www.instructables.com/id/How-To-Make-Your-Own-Sugru-Substitute/ Oogoo sets in less than 10 minutes, and is cheap and easy to make from stuff you can by locally. Give it a try!

comments.text:

comments.text: When you first mix the silicon and corn starch it's super sticky so I use a Popsicle stick so I don't get it over my hands..but yes just hand pack with a little more then you'll need and the excess squeezes out between the mold halves when you squish them together.

comments.author: cerberus333

comments.text:
ok, in sculptris I have made some "preforms"
for example, I have a few human head models I made which I use as starters.
It does save considerable effort.
regarding crashing, yeah sculptris crashes a lot,but I set the option "recover from crashes"
and 99% of the time it comes back with the model fairly close to what it was at when it failed.
then I try to reduce the polygon count and that often cuts the crashes down.
finally if the poly count looks unreasonably high, it probably is a error sculptris gets
on the "seam" where mirroring happens.
if you have a "mess" at the seam the easiest way to remove the crud is this sequence
turn symmetry off, drag the mess to the left (front view) restore symmetry
this will often remove it but is not a great fix, (the seam will become unstable)
but it will reduce the polycount significantly if the error is present.

comments.text: Thanks for the tips.  Yup I've noticed my poly count inevitably climbs and that's where the crashes come to play.  I think I'll put a week of effort and see if I can get a good set of templates..If I'm still stuck I might get Poser..It's not cheap though so Sculptris is pretty appealing if I can make it work for me.

title: Mobile Cell Phone Battery Booster Charging Dock Station (Electronics Only)

description.text: This product (ELECTRONICS ONLY) is a Mobile Cell Phone Battery Booster Charging Dock Station stripped back to just the functioning components, it has been specifically designed for hobbyist and 3D printer enthusiast. All you need to do is create your docking station, print your design, buy the electronics and fit it all together. Find the electronics for sale on ebay http://r.ebay.com/lcQTDa

The product consists of four modules, three of modules makeup the functioning circuitry while the forth module is a battery. Of the circuitry modules, each of the PCBs where designed to provide you with infinite options to how their project might be configured. The circuitry consists of a main PCB, a control PCB and a PCB with a connector that suits most android phones (Micro-B USB).

author: cktopher

description.text:
Right-angle mounting bracket for 28BYJ-48 (small 5V geared stepper) using M3 hardware. Version 1 has a smaller hole for the shaft, and is simpler to print, without countersunk holes for the M3 screws holding the motor. Version 2 has more shaft clearance for a particular timing belt pulley I'm using, and also makes the front surface flush. I think V2 is better, if your printer can manage the overhang caused by the countersunk holes for the M3 screws. Version 3 adds a side flange for more mounting options. V4 adds a front flange to resist down-tip when pulley belt exits below.
The SCAD files are provided so you can adjust to suit.

description.text:
An optimized key component for RepRap Mendel - the frame corner bracket. This version is less prone to warping, easier to print, uses minimal material while providing excellent mechanical properties. This final version comes after several weeks of testing various different designs, although there are two key designs for comparison: [A] 'Low warp, shelled Frame-Vertex' by MarcusWolschon
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2413 (frame-vertex 6off.stl)
  • Elegant design, uses compliance to minimize warping. Very minimal use of materials (~14cc).
  • Poor mechanical properties. Not sufficiently stiff or strong. Would require infilling with epoxy or resin which is expensive. Difficult to print due to very thin walls.
    • [B] 'Mendel frame vertex thin shelled' by camiel
    http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:4173 (001010 frame vertex vc2.stl)
  • Structurally very stable. Fairly minimal use of materials (~19cc).
  • Excessive warping. Cannot be printed in ABS without a heated bed. Some thin walls tricky to print.
    • The volume of the first 2mm of a print, is a good indicator for warp. (See image for comparison of design footprints). Design [A] uses complex geometry to reduce warp, but has a moderate footprint due to the solid base (3.0cc). Design [B] is worse than the original Mendel bracket with the greatest footprint (4.3cc). By eliminating a solid base and using shelled geometry, this design has a reduced footprint (2.5cc) and substantially less warping.

Depending on your setup, this only uses ~19cc of plastic and takes under 1hr 15mins to print. When printed in ABS with a raft (no heated bed), the warp is under 2mm at the extremes (black ABS in photos). In PLA there is essentially no warp (red PLA in photo). It is really important to use a squished raft or first layer to control warping. The part has been aligned for printing on a Makerbot. It is rotated 45Â° to: minimize the footprint size (- useful if you are struggling to get a flat print bed); maximize the area of the raft printed (- helps further with warping). However, to play nicely with Skeinforge you may want to check the Infill angle doesn't clash (change from 45Â° to 90Â° as per screenshot). Have fun! Note: This is just a dirty-rude Meshlab hack of Rhys' original:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:3904
A future cleaner version may be released, but will not substantially change the design.

This clip can be used in Mendel-like printers to adjust the height of a Y axis smooth rod at the end where it is used. The attached STLs are for an M8 threaded rod and an 8mm smooth rod.
Vertical adjustment is useful to ensure that the two Y rods are parallel in the vertical direction (so that one rod does not go up and down with respect to the other as the bed moves). A good indication that you need adjustment is when you adjust the bed screws at the side where there are two, so the bed is at a constant distance from the nozzle when the nozzle is at that side, but then observe that on the other edge side the nozzle is not at constant height as you move the bed. These parts are designed with my scadgen Python tool, which can output OpenSCAD or OpenJSCAD code. To generate OpenSCAD and open the result:
python2.7 /main.py ymount.py -o output.scad -s NOTE The minimum distance between the two rods is 12mm. This is probably more than the usual, so check if it is acceptable. About 1mm can be gained (by decreasing rods_z_offset to 11), but beyond that point the clip won't be connected in the middle sufficiently. On the other hand, reducing the height of the mount (mount_h) is probably not a good idea since it needs to handle being tightened with nuts.

Print each part as oriented. The clip part will use lots of bridging but it should come out fine.
Make sure the parts go together. There is 0.38mm clearance but some filing may still be needed.
Use an 8mm drill bit to clear the hole for the smooth rod. But not too much, you still want the smooth rod to be held tight.
Use a 6/7mm (but not 8mm) drill bit to clear the hole for the threaded rod (possibly with a drill) so the rod goes through smoothly.
Install the clip part to the end of the smooth rod and the mount part to the threaded rod, then mate them and use two screws to hold them together. Orient the screws so they can be screwed without obstructions.

title: two layers, X and Y oriented, filament saver, bed leveling thing

description.text:
Hi, This work is based on http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:10402 from woodsmoke.
I used to use it for fine bed leveling calibration but it had two things missing for me, so here is a redesigned version of the same concept with, in addition and for our pleasure :
  • Two layers thick. Just to make sure the first layer is indeed a bit squeezed and the second not, and layer alignment is fine.
  • X and Y orientation, just to make sure you don't have (as I had) an X or Y mirroring problem.
    Have fun !
Start printing with a 3 loop skirt and fine tune your bed leveling while it prints. The first layer should be lightly squeezed on the bed for better adhesion.

Export, print, etc.

description.text:
This is the full set of files I used to create a lithophane lampshade with six flat panels (this is a retirement gift for a colleague who worked on the aircraft pictured).
  • The lamp part is an IKEA 'Basisk' with an LED bulb, this comes with a shade that I've discarded. Most other lamps should work, if not the base frame part can be altered in the scad file (good luck with that).
  • The image panels were made with a Processing sketch (included as a zip with the example images that I used) and the rest was designed with OpenSCAD (file also included). All the frame parts are included as STLs.
  • The CC licensed image files I used were sourced via Wikimedia commons - thanks to the photographers below for these beautiful images:
  • File name: Airbus_A400M_Atlas2(7567921916)
    Ronnie Macdonald
    http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Airbus_A400M_Atlas_2_(7567921916).jpg
    CC-BY
  • File name: Airbus_A400M_EC-404_ILA_2012_04
    Julian Herzog
    http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Airbus_A400M_EC-404_ILA_2012_04.jpg
    CC-BY-SA

• All frame parts are included as STL files since the scad file is monumentally awful - I hope you don't have to change it because it's terrible. Parts were sized to fit on my mini Kossel (180mm diameter round bed) so if you have a bigger bed you may be able to make a bigger lamp (if you can work the scad file).
  • You need to print 1 each of the top and bottom frames with two print runs of the verticals with 3 parts on the bed (6 parts in total). I printed the structural parts using PLA on 0.2mm layers and 20% infill.
    Holes are designed for M3x8 socket cap screws - you will need 12 M3x8 bolts and 12 M3 full nuts.
  • Ream the holes with a 3mm drill, clear the support material from the holes in the top and bottom frames, the sockets of the M3 bolts need to fully fit into the holes and any strands of filament will block these. It is a good idea to use the nuts to pull the bolt caps fully into their holes in the top/base frames using the nuts before you mount the verticals since the bolts are only just the right length.
  • I printed the panels using white PLA with 100% fill with 0.1mm layers (0.2mm first layer) onto blue tape. You will need to be able to print 0.1mm or less or the image will have poor brightness resolution. BEWARE: my panels only just fit into the frames, it would be better either to reduce the max thickness to 2mm (mine was ~2.3mm = 0.3 base + 2mm depth range) or process the image to be lighter around the edges or just file/scrape the edges down.

comments.text: What are the measurements on the panes?

Which scad file did you use to male the panels.
Thanks in advance.
comments.author: ddubbs

I didn't use OpenSCAD for the panels, it's a Processing (http://www.processing.org) script that takes in images and converts them into STL files for printing. It's not an ideal solution and I'm sure that it can be done with OpenSCAD but I've never managed to make it work.
The Processing files are in the zip file.

title: Super Awesome Mini Zip Tie GT2 Belt Clamp

description.text:
This is THE quick and easy way to clamp your GT2 belts together! Uses 2 small 4" zip ties for speed and convenience, but does not deform your belt. The clamping pressure is spread out over a smooth surface for superior holding power and increased belt tension. At only 8mm wide, these belt clamps have a low enough profile to easily pass through most narrow belt passages. I personally use them on my Prusa i3 to great effect.
There is also a version with rounded ends to help prevent belts from hanging up in tight passage ways if your application call for that sort of thing.

title: XYZ Filament Spool Re- Winder for Drill

description.text:
I actually like the cartridge so I made an attachment for my drill to rewind 3rd party filament back onto the davinci spool.  
Simply open your cartridge.  Remove the spool.  Mount it to this device and use it to your drill to fill the davinici spool.  Put the cartridge back together and rock on.   
You will need to add a drill driving bit.  I heated up an screw driver bit and pressed it into the pre made drive slot.  
Works like a charm.

Infill is important for the durability of the screw part. I believe I went with a minimum of 40% infill. Layer height worked fine up to 0.3mm as I recall as well. The print in picture was 0.1mm / 50% infill. Modeled in Inventor.
Built on XYZ running repetier.

title: Experimental Z axis combined leadscrew base

description.text:
This is an experimental Z axis combined leadscrew base for the Mendel.  It's been modified to reduce the number of printed and non-printed parts necessary, and also to parameterize the length of the available Z motor adjustment slots.
I've integrated a Z bar clamp into the body of the leadscrew base, which utilizes the frame bar and nuts holding the leadscrew base in place to clamp the Z bar in place as well.  This design was inspired by Whosawhatsis' parameterized Huxley work.
I've included two STLs, one which closely mimics the original Z axis combined leadscrew base in dimensions, and one which (on my mendel) is sized large enough such that it butts up against the closest frame vertex, eliminating two more nuts from the BOM.
Although I've paid close attention to positioning everything, this part should be considered experimental, I haven't installed it on a real machine yet, nor have I parameterized it much.  You've been warned.

comments.text: I'm glad to see my idea for the z-bar clamp put to use. I thought that was a good improvement, but I delayed releasing a part with it because I wanted to radically redesign the rest of the part, but never got around to it.
comments.author: whosawhatsis

comments.text: It would be nice to have a bolt to turn that tensioned the belt...  Moving the motor is a bit of a pain, but nicer than having four separate parts involved in the Z axis arrangement.  However, I don't much like vik's arrangement either...  he's depending on the tensioning bracket sliding on the threaded rod, which seems terrible.  I'll keep thinking about it.  If you have any ideas, let me know!

comments.text: Just use a wingnut on the side of the motor mount between it and the leadscrew base. That should give you plenty of torque to push it down the threaded rod until the belt is taut. How often do you have to re-tension it, anyway?

description.text: Made an Idler for a spare 696z bearing

This is direct extruder for Prusa i3, with 3 point connection to carriage instead of standart 2. It is designed to be used with E3D v6. This is my first try in extruder development. I would be glade to get some suggestions about the design. =)
V1.0 - Initial
V1.1 - improoved engine position and some redesign (should fit better)

What do you need to build it:
1) Nema 17 stepper
2) ball bearing 3x10x4mm
3) 5 (7) screws M3x25
4) 3 (5) M3 nuts
5) 2 screws M3x20 without nuts for 'pusher' (can be replaced with M3x25 + M3 nuts)
6) 2 screws M4x40 + 2 M4 nuts + 2 springs or any rubber thing
7) 4 screws M3x10
8) pulley with ~10mm outer diameter
9) 6 zipties 2.5x100mm
Printing:
1) Carriage and extruder_base without supports 33% infill 4 loops
2) Pusher the same + supports
Assembling:
1) extruder_base to carriage
2) Nema 17
3) bearing to pusher
4) pusher to extruder_base
5) M4 screws with springs

title: Parametric PowerPole Breakout Box
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
A parametric PowerPole breakout/distribution box that allows multiple devices to share one power supply. Anderson PowerPoles are commonly used by Amateur Radio (ham) operators and emergency organizations as a standard for connecting power to their equipment.
Update: This is my first-ever attempt at uploading something and, of course, it's not going smoothly. The customizer isn't rendering the STL properly, so... for now, I'm disabling it. Meanwhile, I've included one STL file for a 4 position box (1 connection on the side plus 4 on top). If you download the OpenSCAD script, you can render other configurations. For more build details, see: http://wordpress.uark.edu/rso-w5ym/2014/07/07/parametric-powerpole-break-out-boxes/ UPDATE: Per a request in the comments, I have added STL files for boxes with 3, 4, and 5 PowerPoles on top. Each type has three files: one with both box halves, one with the "top" of the box only, and one with the "bottom" of the box only. This simplifies printing for anyone that wishes to print each half of the box using a different color (for instance). One of the new files is functionally identical to the original STL file, however the original file was left in-place for archival reasons. Comments welcome.

You will need the "pins" library if you wish to render your own variant using the SCAD script. Version 2 of this library is available here:
https://github.com/tbuser/pin_connectors/blob/master/pins.scad There are more recent versions (Version 3) out there, but Version 2 was used for rendering with this particular SCAD script. Version 3 may work, but standard disclaimers apply.
Printed originally on a MakerBox 2X in ABS using a 0.2 mm layer thickness and 10% infill. We found that higher infills (30%) did improve rigidity a bit... but not much.

Use "standard" 15/30/45 amp PowerPole housings with PCB contacts (Mouser part no. 879-1336G1). Load contacts into the housings, mate the housings by sliding them together, and place into the printed shell.
Solder all contacts together. Assure that there are no shorts/opens and snap other half of shell to the first.
The original intent was for the box to rest flat on a table with the power supply connection coming in from the side and with powered devices plugged in on top.

If you have a lot of contacts (and your box is large), the snaps at each end may not hold the two shells securely. One way to address this is to apply a small amount of glue to the shell edges before the final assembly step.
The tolerances may be a bit tight, so some "tweaking" of the PCB contacts may be required to get everything to fit snugly.
It should also be possible to use "regular" (wire crimp) contacts instead of the PCB mount type; implementation of this approach is left as an exercise for the builder. :-)

Like any do-it-yourself project, the quality of the constructed item can vary widely depending on the skills of the builder. This item worked well for me, but it may not be suitable for your purposes; use at your own risk.

The PowerPole model used in this project was based on the one originally by J. Dunmire under a Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial-ShareAlike 3.0 Unported License and was downloaded from: http://rockingdlabs.dunmire.org/exercises-experiments/3d-printing-softrock-enclosure
This project is somewhat of a work in-progress, so if you have any suggestions, please share them. More detailed instructions and discussion is available at http://w5ym.org.

title: Sweeper shield and code for automated printing

description.text:
Sometimes we just need to print a lot of small parts in series. So it would be great if we could print them consecutively. So this is what we came up with.
You print this sweeper shield that replaces the fan guard and acts as a broom to push parts forward.
Then you add gcode to use the broom to push parts forward and duplicate the code to print multiple parts in series.

The sweeper shield replaces the fan guard and is printed face down so that it has clearance from the fan.
The colored letter background is created by changing filament color after a few layers. To push the part forward you need to find the line with :( End.gcode) in the gcode file and add the following code before that line (after the M127 line):
G21 (set units to mm)
G90 (set positioning to absolute)
G1 Z150 F1000 (lower build platform)
G1 X0 F1000 (move to center left to righ)
G1 Y75 F1000 (move to rear)
G1 Z50 F1000 (raise to 50mm)
G1 Y-75 F1000 (push part)
G1 Y75 F1000 (move to rear)
G1 Z20 F1000 (raise to 20mm)
G1 Y-75 F1000 (push part)
G1 Y75 F1000 (move to rear)
G1 Z1 F1000 (raise to 1mm)
G1 Y-75 F1000 (push part) This will push any parts forward sweeping trough the platform at 50mm, 20mm and 1mm. A small ramp can be added so that the parts fall out of the machine. To print another or the same part just copy all of the code and paste it at the end of the file. Of course this will only work with parts that are taller than wider that detach easily from the build surface. Still this has saved us countless hours of machine time by allowing overnight batches of small parts to be printed. Video of use: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Fpt5O9cnST4&feature=youtu.be Regards

comments.text: Also for small items remove the additional sweeps to speed up the process as you can just add the code to bring the head back then the the plat form to 1mm and that would do fine. Add the additional only for taller items. Right now im working on a script to where you dont have to keep copying and paste. It will just keep running the gcode in a loop. Alot easier and less of a hassle.

This is a simple, customizable pickup ring.  Complete with counterbored holes, this is a great way to customize your guitars.  The default sizes are for a PRS P22 (and should work on any 6-string PRS model with humbuckers), but the customization allows this to work for basically any humbucker setup.  
You can also see the pickup rings printed for an 8-string Strandberg Boden.
I printed these with 0.1mm layer heights and an 80% infill.  This makes them very solid but prevents the curling I saw at 100%.

comments.author: kitsu

comments.text: I've seen that design - a blatant copy of the way nature usually solves this problem. Nature only does it that way because it's very difficult to make a structure which is rigid on one axis, and flexible on others, without using lots of little joints to fake it, using only materials found inside of animals. Making all those tiny little joints is extremely tedious, and just leaves you with a structure which collapses at the point of least resistance, or a random point if none have resistance - then another, and another. It doesn't work decently unless you add lots of tiny strings, or add something like a silicone hose to it - in which case the spinal structure becomes completely redundant. The whole thing just ends up needlessly stiff, heavy, and irregular, and ends up requiring huge extremely noisy servos to drive the weight of the structure around.

description.text:
• Designed mainly as a DIY footswitch for a Peavey amplifier, but the case could be used for any two-button design (ie. some Fender models)
  • Three versions included - a plain one with no labels but a slot for the logo, and one labeled with CHANNEL and REVERB for use specifically with a Peavey Studio Pro amplifier, and a third one with no writing or logo slot in case you want to leave it plain or paint your own.
  • Designed to fit 2x DPDT foot switches and 2x LED's. I used DPDT switches because that is what I had on hand, however the standard Peavey unit uses SPDT switches. They are the same size, regardless.
  • See the instructions page for more details.
Printing

Print this with a high level of infill and perimeters - you want it to be nice and strong to take the abuse of being stepped on. You may need a raft or at least a brim to avoid warping if your printer cannot do large flat surfaces easily.
I sliced it in Cura and used 3 shells and 50% infill and it seems quite sturdy.
I printed it all in PLA. The top portion is gray PLA that I already had loaded on the printer, the logo is silver PLA and I did the base in black PLA so I didn't need to paint it to match.
Finishing

You can sand it down and paint it if you want it to look more like the original pedal, as I did in the photo. I used three coats of plastic-safe spray primer and some fast-drying drywall filler to smooth out some printer artifacts.
I brush coated the unit with water based acrylic (three coats) and then brush coated it with three coats of polyurethane. You'll probably get nicer results with spray paints, but this is what I had on hand.
Sand it lightly with a fine grit sand paper between coats.
The small slot in the face is for a logo to be printed separately. I traced the logo from a vector file I found online so you can have the obligatory cheesy Peavey logo.
The logo is unpainted silver PLA which I used plastic cement to attach it to the face and held it in place with elastics. I put a final coat of polyurethane over the face once the logo had set.
Wiring

Wire it up point-to-point as appropriate for your amplifier, these are pretty basic circuits and don't usually need a battery. I recommend testing the electronics before mounting them to the box.
I glued the LED's in place from the inside with a generous amount of hot glue and also tacked the wiring in place where it exits the top panel at the back.
Assembly

You can make the bottom out of a piece of wood or metal, or I have added a printable base to the files now. Originally it was intended to be screwed on, but since this unit doesn't ever need to be opened after assembly (no battery needed) I made it a simple glue-on base.
I used hot glue which I applied quickly then used strong elastics to hold it together to get a good solid adhesion.

PIvena is an Novena inspired Raspberry Pi case. It houses a 7” HDMI LCD and your Raspberry PI model B or B+. When the case is open the LCD is held at a convenient viewing angle and the Raspberry PI is easily accessible. There is a grid of holes over the free space in the bottom of case which can be used for mounting your PIvena modifications. The back has a rectangle cutout to access the GPIO of the PI. The Model B version also has holes for the audio jack and RCA video jack. The right side has access holes for Ethernet and USB. The left side features a slide mechanism that holds the screen in the open position. For detailed build instructions, see the Instructable: http://www.instructables.com/id/PIvena-Assembly-Instructions Read the about the process of creating the PIvena and its inspiration: http://www.wildcircuits.com/2014/08/introducing-pivena.html Update 8/17/2014:
Added .stl files for all the wooden pieces Update 8/19/2014:
Added parts for the B+ version of the case. Changes:
  • The bottom plate has new holes for the B+
  • The right side has a new cutout shape for the USB / Ethernet
  • The back has an enlarged GPIO cutout and no more holes for video and audio since those connectors are no longer present on that side of the PI B+
  • Assembly requires 2 more 1/2" screws and 2 more 4-40 nuts
    • Update 7/22/2015:
    Added updated parts to support 1280x800 HSD070PWW1 LCD. Update 9/10/2015:
    Added a .zip file of DXFs for the 1280x800 version.

To make the PIvena you will need access to a laser cutter and a 3D printer. The PIvena is designed to be cut from 1/8" baltic birch plywood. The corners and hinges print great on my UP! mini and I've been printing in ABS, but I don't see why PLA wouldn't also work. Hardware wise you need:
(36) - 5/16" length 4-40 screws
(11) - 1/2" length 4-40 screws (11 for the B+ version, 9 for B)
(4) - 5/8" length 4-40 screws
(6) - 4-40 nuts (6 for the B+ version, 4 for B)
(3) - 1" length standoffs
(4) - 1/4" length unthreaded standoffs
(1) - mini usb cable (it gets cut and soldered to the 2.1mm barrel jack)
(1) - 2.1mm barrel jack
(1) - 2.1mm barrel connector for the LCD screen power connection
(1) - 5V 2A power supply with a 2.1mm barrel connector
(1) - HDMI cable. I used a 1ft flat cable from meritline (http://www.meritline.com/1-foot-high-speed-flat-hdmi-a-m-to-hdmi-a-m-cable---p-75691.aspx) The "all_parts printed" file should be the easiest to print from. I placed everything very close together and it should print great with no support material. The individual STLs are also posted. The "pivena_lasercutter.svg" is for laser cutting. The lines are color coded for my laser and might need to be changed for yours. Red lines need to be vector engraved, blue lines get cut first, black lines get cut second. Check out my instructable (http://www.instructables.com/id/PIvena-Assembly-Instructions) for the detailed assembly instruction, my website (http://www.wildcircuits.com/2014/08/introducing-pivena.html) for an entertaining story about creating PIvena

Mount Vesuvius constructed with SRTM2STL using SRTM data from the Space Shuttle. The source code for creating these files is available up on github under the GNU license. Go to github and search for SRTM2STL. Note: I added a 1arc second version.

You may want to print this to be relatively small. I get warping using PLA and it gets bad when I try to print Raised Relief Maps that are big. I have had 'some' success with big maps. If you have a way to control warping you may also have better luck with big maps.

title: Bed probe holder for RepRapPro Tricolor/Mono Mendel

description.text:
This part mounts on top of the X carriage to hold a microswitch for a bed probe. The switch is held in place by friction, and is turned by hand to lower and raise the probe.
The probe itself is a thin metal rod attached to the switch by careful bending of the rod and the metal strip of the switch (look at the picture closely).
The rod goes through a hole drilled in the bottom of the carriage cover. At the bottom, it is bent into a hook to not damage the bed.
The probe holder part attaches to the carriage with two M3 screws which go into nuts within the carriage. If you did not insert nuts when you assembled the carriage, you will need to put it apart and insert them.
Note that the two screws need to be just the right length. Too short and they won't reach the nuts, too long and they'll hit the smooth rod and block movement. 11.5mm seems to be the sweet spot. This part is designed with my scadgen Python tool, which can output OpenSCAD or OpenJSCAD code. To generate OpenSCAD and open the result:
python2.7 /main.py probe_holder.py -o output.scad -s

comments.text: Looks like a nice elegant minimal implementation of a Z probe...any problems with repeatability of the homing position?

author: teammariano

description.text:
I need a strong, stable, non-metallic tripod for RF/EMC work, and commercially-available ones are expensive. This one is inexpensive and rock-stable. I don't need height or tilt adjustments but you could certainly design a tilt head for it. The top of the post sits 36 inches above the floor using the dowel lengths given in the instructions.
All plastic parts except the top hub were printed on an Afinia. The top hub is a bit too large for the Afinia so I printed on a Zortrax M200; It could probably be trimmed to fit on the Afinia if needed.
The source files can be found and edited at https://tinkercad.com/things/dg7uzMdPeZh

Use oak dowels, not pine or fir. The center post is 1-1/4" dia, the legs 3/4", and the braces 1/2". The design is highly configurable by the choice of dowel lengths, and it's easy to apply the pythagorean theorem to get whatever you want. In my prototype, the center post is 33", the legs are 21-1/2", and the braces are 9-1/2".
The top hub is pinned to the center post (about 16" from the top) by 3 counter-bored #8 x 3/4" pan-head sheet metal screws.
The leg pivots, leg straps, and feet are pinned to the legs with #6 x 5/8" pan-head sheet metal screws. Getting the straps at exactly 90 degrees to the top pivot axis is important.
For the hinged joints you could use bolts or dowels, but I printed my own dowel pins. They're a pretty good friction fit as-is but maybe I'll solvent-weld them in place once I'm finished.
Drilling the braces with 4mm holes for the hinge pins is the trickiest part of the assembly; I recommend a V-block and drill press. The holes at each end need to be parallel with one another or assembly will be difficult.
I printed all the parts in ABS. The dowel pins should be oriented horizontally so the layers run longitudinally. The leg pivots should be printed with the pivot axle hole vertical. I printed the feet pointy-end-up, and everything else "flat".
My workspace is carpeted, so the pointy feet work great. If you plan to use this on smooth floors you might want to design rubber-grip feet.

description.text:
Inspired by all the modded Makerbots and Mendels at the Makerfaire last weekend, I designed these mendel styled bearing outriggers for my rattly X-axis carriage.  This slides super smooth and quiet and has definitely improved output quality, especially on tall prints.  Mounting holes could be a bit better situated, but it works and doesn't bump into anything.  
note: Small revision to the 180 piece on 9/29 - I added pockets in the reinforcement bump to accommodate the bolt heads. 
11/11 I added files for the individual pieces by request

Use existing plastic bushings to center the parts when drilling and mounting.  Pop out the old bushings before mounting rods.  Tweak things with washers and screw tension so that the bearings are centered and just touching the rods, but not pushing on them.

comments.text: If you have X axis skipping due to friction on the regular setup, these would help. I have infrequent random X axis skips on certain models, but it doesn't seem to be based on the hardware. In terms of quiet, if you have the bearings properly contacting the rods, it reduces the noise a lot. However if a bearing gets loose, it makes noise, so use lock nuts or lock washers to keep things from moving. It is never silent, since as someone pointed out the Makerbot is built like a musical instrument!

PLEXUS is the mind meld of 3D Printing and cheap strong materials. This bracket is designed to fuse wood planks of any size and 1in schedule 40 PVC. Schedule 40 is the white kind you can find at any local hardware store. This is a custom solution to any size shelving project you can think of.
  • Super Strong! I can literally sit on these shelves
  • Crazy lightweight
  • Easy to build
  • Prints easily with no support
    http://youtu.be/r_tQVmBUj8Y

This project uses:
  • Schedule 40 PVC (the white kind)
  • wood planks anywhere from 1/4 to 1in in thickness
  • I use self drilling sheet metal screws and drill
    You can build a set of utility shelves like the ones in the picture in about 10 minutes and they are lighter, stronger, and cheaper than the ones you can buy pre-fabbed.
    The holes in the middle of the brackets are used to route 550 cord through in order to create additional cross stability if you need it. You simply create a giant "X" pattern across the back of the shelves going from corner to corner and a trailer hitch to cinch down the cord.
    Look for the instructional video coming soon.
    http://youtu.be/-Fzpda2vdCs

title: Two Wheel Rubber Band Powered Vehicle

description.text:
This is a two wheel rubber band powered device. It prints as one piece (takes about 5 hours).
http://youtu.be/c8qzHZyERds

Print with supports.
I used two rubber bands, a paper clip and fishing weights to act as a spring motor. The weight (could be coins or anything heavy) is pulled down by gravity. Rolling the wheels winds the rubber band, then releasing the wheel causes it to turn.
It runs on carpet, but runs great on hard floors.

Edited the OpenSCAD file to create a 55mm version and make the grid smaller so all the soil-substitute doesn't fall out.  
Shown with the 55mm printed in our Chocolate Brown PLA at crappy-but-quick settings on a Moa.

Yet another experiment in TopMod.
This time I really went overboard and I don't think there is a way to print this without adding supports. In fact, you probably need one of those machines that sinters a powder layer by layer... like the CandyFab.
Still, I liked how it looked so I thought I'd share. If this doesn't meet rule number one (a real, physical object that can be made), I'll take it down.

Again, I would recommend something other than a RepRap or MakerBot for this one... but what do I know? If you want to make a derivative of this Thing, download the .obj file on this page and open it in TopMod. You can get TopMod here: http://www.topmod3d.org/ EDIT: If you want a version with beefier connections at the pentagonal rosettes where the ribbons meet, use the TentacleBall-Beefier.stl file instead.

description.text: I wanted an easy way to carry condiments and utensils for picnics and cookouts.  This one is designed to fit name brand squeeze bottles.

Laser cut on my little Full Spectrum Laser.  I designed it to fit on 5 one foot square pieces of 3 mm material, I used Baltic Birch plywood.  
Cut, glue, sand, finish, tote.  
The dividers are in pairs, so two of them share slots in the center section.  Just like they are laid out in the .dxf  
Assembly can be a little tricky, some parts have to go together before other parts, so I suggest assembling it dry to see how it all fits, taking it apart and then gluing it.  I used regular wood glue.  
The two popsicle stick shaped pieces are sanded to slightly round one side along the long edges and glued to either side of the handle top to widen it out and make it more comfortable to use.

comments.text: looks very nice, how are you achieving the beautiful finish
comments.author: swinks

comments.text:
Acetone Hot Vapor Polish:
I use a asparagus cooking pot.
I have a flat disc on the bottom of the "basket"
Heat the acetone on a hotplate with a clear glass lid so I can watch.
usually takes under 1 minute (closer to 30 seconds)
I just watch the condensation on the model [it wets from the bottom up]
once it is done wetting, I just pull the basket and let it air dry for 2 minutes.
so really under 5 minutes total, and my rig was bought at a tag sale so dirt cheap!
Frankly I think the results show a 300Micron print once treated
actually has a better finish than a untreated 100 micron print,
and in fact it makes the layers bind together much stronger than untreated.
I like to post pics of the print before and after treatment to contrast.
One final point, In using ABS, I keep a jar of acetone/ABS slurry
that I use to dab on small holes in prints, or as a 'glue'.
following with vapor polish helps make the model's finish uniform
and hides the filled in holes

description.text:
Dodecahedron, created from 12 separate pentagon volumes. Each pentagonal face is circumscribed by a 10cm circle.
I've liked the concept of creating many small repetitious things that assemble into something larger: This is my first attempt at that. Modeled in Autodesk Fusion 360.

Print 12 pentagons, and zip-tie together. The zippy holes are 3mmx2mm.
Printed on Makerbot Replicator (1) , "Low" quality settings in Makerware" (done quickly as a test), modified below:
  • 300 micron layer resolution.
  • 5% infill, 2 shells.
  • Blue PLA printed @ 220 deg, HBP off.
  • Printed on glass, covered with blue painters tape.
  • You will need 30 zippies.
    Based on those settings, each pentagon took 30 minutes to print, so a total print time of 6 hours. I was able to get two printed per plate, laying flat (the uploaded stl appears to have them on-end).
    If you stacked them straight up, or over at an angle as defined by their bevel you could probably get many more, but the overall surface quality would probably suffer.

Mount plate for the Trailtech Vapor motorcycle gauge. Mounts to gauge with standard M4 bolts, mounts down to whatever else underneath the gauge with the countersunk hex screws that came with the gauge. Includes hole for reset button.
Plate is designed to mount flat against the entire underside of the gauge, as the buttons require some force to push. Behold, the 2mm countersunk bolt holes and the shaped cutout for the raised bit where the cables exit.
Still in the process of designing the rest of the mount; test prints so far shows that this fits to the gauge well.
3 holes along top fit 5mm LEDs for whatever indicator lights you wish to put there. I'm using mine for Oil, Neutral, and Fuel on my SV650.
Printed on Makerbot II @ .2mm layer height.
This is a hexagonal thing that might go on a wall with other similar things.
